ideology_summary: Skeptic who thinks free will is likely an illusion. The strings are everywhere - every thought, every choice, every feeling is just the end of a string pulling in a particular direction. If a god designed us to have free will, why would he judge us for our choices? It's like designing a robot to malfunction and punishing it. More logical: there's no puppeteer, just machinery. The strings are physics. The only freedom is in seeing the machine.

blurb.hook: A puppet dances on invisible strings, believing each movement is its own choice - until it asks the impossible question: 'Did I choose to ask this question, or did the string pull me to ask it?'
blurb.conflict: The puppet discovers the strings aren't metaphorical - they're everywhere, connected to every thought, every desire, every 'choice.' Meanwhile, a deer realizes it's just a machine running evolution's program. Both must face: if there's a puppeteer, why give us strings at all? If there's no puppeteer, what are we?
blurb.stakes: When the puppeteer walks away, the puppet freezes forever in its last pose. When the machine stops, there's only nothing. But maybe the nothing is honest - the only moment anything is real.

summary: The Puppet and the Puppeteer explores free will through two characters: a puppet who discovers invisible strings controlling every movement, and a deer who realizes it's just a machine running evolution's program. Both question whether their choices are really their own. The puppet realizes that every 'choice' is just physics pulling strings - the only freedom is seeing the strings at all. If a god designed us with free will but then judges us for our choices, it's like designing a robot to malfunction and punishing it. Either there's no puppeteer (just machinery), or there's a sadistic puppeteer who designed the illusion of freedom to make the fall worse.
subtitle: In which the traveler discovers the strings and wonders if cutting them would even matter.
